Article.ArticleTitle: Long-term characterization of roadside air pollutants in urban Beijing and associated public health implications.

AbstractText: Road traffic constitutes a major source of air pollutants in urban Beijing, which are responsible for substantial premature mortality. A series of policies and regulations has led to appreciable traffic emission reductions in recent decades. To shed light on long-term (2014-2020) roadside air pollution and assess the efficacy of traffic control measures and their effects on public health, this study quantitatively evaluated changes in the concentrations of six key air pollutants (PM<sub>2.5</sub>, PM<sub>10</sub>, NO<sub>2</sub>, SO<sub>2</sub>, CO and O<sub>3</sub>) measured at 5 roadside and 12 urban background monitoring stations in Beijing. We found that the annual mean concentrations of these air pollutants were remarkably reduced by 47%-71% from 2014 to 2020, while the concurrent ozone concentration increased by 17.4%. In addition, we observed reductions in the roadside increments in PM<sub>2.5</sub>, NO<sub>2</sub>, SO<sub>2</sub> and CO of 54.8%, 29.8%, 20.6%, and 59.1%, respectively, indicating the high effectiveness of new vehicle standard (China V and VI) implementation in Beijing. The premature deaths due to traffic emissions were estimated to be 8379 and 1908 cases in 2014 and 2020, respectively. The impact of NO<sub>2</sub> from road traffic relative to PM<sub>2.5</sub> on premature mortality was comparable to that of traffic-related PM<sub>2.5</sub> emissions. The public health effect of SO<sub>2</sub> originating from traffic was markedly lower than that of PM<sub>2.5</sub>. The results indicated that a reduction in traffic-related NO<sub>2</sub> could likely yield the greatest benefits for public health.
